item.title: They Got the Spectrum. It Still Didn't Help.
item.description: Here is the thing about anomalies in mainstream physics: they get explained eventually. The continental drift people waited decades but it came through. Ball lightning has been documented since the 1600s, is acknowledged in Physical Review Letters and Nature, has eyewitness accounts matching across languages and centuries, got captured by scientific instruments in 2014 - and the field’s current position is still, essentially: we have several theories, none of them quite work, please don’t make this awkward at conferences.

item.title: Everybody Found the Fishing Line. Nobody Checked the Metal Samples.
item.description:
There is fishing line in the video.

Upper-left corner. 1990 footage of a toy UFO levitating. The line moves exactly when the UFO moves. A skeptic pointed this out. Hutchison admitted it. He’d been “creative” with the footage, he said. He hadn’t reproduced the effect reliably since 1991.

This is where most people stop. Fishing line. Admitted fabrications. Case closed. Hoax. Next.

What nobody talks about is Hathaway.

John Hutchison has lived on a disability pension in Vancouver for most of his adult life. He salvages electromagnetic equipment from military surplus stores and junkyards. He’s been obsessing over Nikola Tesla’s research since childhood, building an increasingly complicated array of Tesla coils and electrostatic generators and RF oscillators in his apartment. In 1979, while running multiple generators simultaneously, something hit him in the shoulder. He threw it back. It flew up and hit him again.

item.title: The Man Who Patented What Can't Exist
item.description:
Patent number 5,054,046 was issued by the United States Patent and Trademark Office on October 1, 1991.

Read the abstract. It describes a device for isolating “charge clusters” - dense, self-organized bundles of electrons that form spontaneously in pulsed electrical discharges, maintain coherent structure against thermodynamic predictions, and generate electromagnetic effects that exceed anything classical physics says should be happening at that scale.

The USPTO is not a gullible institution. They categorically reject perpetual motion machines. They rejected cold fusion applications. Their standard for exotic physics claims is: demonstrate it, replicate it, show it works. They are the original show-don’t-tell agency. And they issued Ken Shoulders five patents on objects that, according to the textbooks, cannot stably exist.

item.title: Seventy Thousand Degrees in a Water Glass
item.description:
They discovered it with sonar equipment in 1934. They said they had more important matters. They did.

There is a bubble of air at the center of a glass flask. Someone turns on a speaker. It expands â€” swells to fifty microns, about half the width of a human hair. Then the acoustic wave flips. The pressure outside reverses. The atmosphere decides it’s done being polite.

What happens next takes less than a nanosecond.
